description.narrative: At the request of Governments and social partners , the ILO has agreed to support mutual learning and voluntary peer review across member States in the field of employment.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 2.1 # of peer-learning events successfully conducted 2.2 # of participants in the MLP

comment.narrative: 2.1. MLP piloted during phase 1 of the project with 2 peer-learning events 2.2. Delegations of 2 or 3 representatives per country/territory have participated in previous peer-learning exchanges

.2.1. 2 MLP conducted on profiling and operational planning. 2nd peer exchange on: Profiling labour market disadvantage organized for 6 WB representatives of the PES and the ministries in charge for labour and employment. The event took place in May 2019, with 18 participants (15 women). Delegations prepared their inputs during March/April and recommendations were validated in June/July. EU PES experts joined the 2nd peer-learning event (Profiling) to present Profiling systems in Ireland (Barry Kennedy, Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection of Ireland) and Sequence of services and programme targeting different client profiles in France (Nathalie Nedellec, Project Manager of the French Pôle Emploi). 2nd event: Each participating country has prepared report on profiling according to the guidelines and technical note prepared by the project technical team and distributed to the participating institutions (total of 6 country specific reports – WB6). 2.2. 3rd peer exchange on: Employment policy implementation mechanisms: Annual Operational Plans organized in September for 22 participants (12 women) from 6 Western Balkans economies, plus Ukraine and Moldova. Delegations prepared their inputs during July and August and recommendations were validated in December. EU experts joined the 3rd peer-learning event (Operational Planning) to present Performance Management in Employment Service of Slovenia (Sonja Pihner, Senior Employment Advisor at the Employment Service Slovenia) and Romanian Labour Market Situation, Strategic and Legislative Framework (Cristian Raileanu, Senior Advisor in Directorate for Employment Policies, Competencies and Professional Mobility of the Romanian Ministry of Labour and Social Justice). 3rd event: Each participating country has prepared presentation on institutional mechanisms for annual operational planning following the technical guidelines and brief technical note on operational planning prepared by the ILO technical team.
1.1.3 mutual learning events organized 1.2. 80

1.1. Due to COVID-19 related restrictions the peer-learning events on monitoring of ALMPs; evaluation of PES Performance and use of IT tools in PES Work have been postponed. As part of the preparation of the mutual learning events i) 6 technical briefs and 6 guidance notes prepared for participants; ii) 32 national reports from participating countries received, analyzed and peer reviewed; iii) 5 EU PES representatives shared experience and guidance (Portugal, Ireland, France, Romania, Slovenia); iv) 3 workshops held and v) 3 detailed technical reports with over 50 recommendations and steps forward for participating institutions designed and confirmed by PESs; vi) 6 sets of recommendations from Participatory Inclusiveness Assessment (phase 1) validated and vii) 10 request for technical assistance stemming from recommendations submitted by the ministries in charge for labour and PES. 1.2. Mutual learning events have been postponed to 2021
2.1. 7 mutual learning programmes 2.2. 200 participants

description.narrative: Territorial employment pacts (TEPs), as a model of mobilizing all local resources for expanding the employment opportunities of individuals with low levels of employability and multiple barriers to entering the labour market.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 3.1. (cumulative) # of local communities that have established strategic partnership and engagement by the private sector and CSOs (SDG indicator 17.1). 3.2. # of innovative financing products and mechanism available for the first-time entrepreneurs and SMEs that also promote youth and/or women employment. 3.3. # of countries/territory have introduced a system for monitoring the impact of the inclusive employment actions on the achievement of SDGs with a focus on SDG 8, SDG 1, SDG 5 and SDG 10 nexus.

comment.narrative: 3.1. Engagement of municipalities, education institutions, CSOs were secured during ILMS 1 yet no significant engagement by private sector. 3.2. 0 – Employment and private sector development financed from government or donor grant fundes or standard micro and medium sized loans 3.3. UNDP’s gender-sensitive master toolkits are available to monitor and assess impacts of inclusive employment

3.1. Capacity development for TEPs has started to ensure sustainability beyond the project. Revitalized Sarajevo Cantonal Council, in BiH, involves private and public sector reps. Local action plan for employment finalized in Feb 2020.Mentorship programme was provided to 94 PES self-employment grantees in Montenegro for finance & legal affairs, marketing, business development, planning – to be continued in 2021 cycle. 3.2. At sub-regional level, UNDP and EIF agreed to conceptualize an Inclusive Growth Facility which aims at crowding in private sector financing to generate jobs, expand skills building opportunities, trigger territorial development and digitalization of MSMEs in the WB6. 3.3. SDG-aligned model for monitoring the impact of inclusive employment actions began. “Impact measurement and monitoring of integrated service delivery by public employment and social welfare services” drafted. A Step-by-step methodology with KPIs will be delivered 2020q1. In Serbia, a technical monitoring framework to assess the contributions of inclusive employment actions to SDG achievement is being developed Evaluation of Local Employment Action Plans in Serbia was completed and published.

3.1. In BiH, the Cantonal Labour Market Reform and Human Resources Development Council was revitalized. Together with the Ministry of Work and Social Policy, comprehensive consultations conducted with representatives of ca. 20 private and public actors. The territorial audit report (review of opportunities and labour force trends to identify bottlenecks) and the assessment of impact of previous ALMPs have been completed. The local action plan for employment, which also entails partners from the private sector, is expected to be finalised in February 2020. 3.2. At sub-regional level, UNDP and EIF agreed to conceptualize a joint financing instrument for SME development and job creation in the Western Balkans. The Inclusive Growth Facility aims at crowding in private sector financing to generate jobs, expand skills building opportunities and trigger territorial development in the Western Balkans. The instrument will provide selected financial intermediaries with a cap guarantee, on condition that deployed loans to SMEs fulfill determined eligibility criteria and participate in the acceleration of the SDGs. This facility is planned to be leveraged for the progress of this activity under ILMS II which envisaged innovative financing opportunities for inclusive employment. 3.3. At sub-regional level, the TOR was prepared for SDG-aligned jmpact measurement and monitoring of integrated service delivery by public employment and social welfare services. A Step-by-step methodology with KPIs will be delivered as a result of this work package. In Serbia, the consultants are engaged to develop methodology for impact evaluation of LAPs. The deliverable is due end of February 2020. The draft impact measurement framework will be finalized and necessary service procurement shall be completed by the second quarter of 2020. Serbia has also been identified to pilot the SDG-aligned monitoring of inclusive employment actions. In addition, concerning ILO/PES Guidance tool on Decentralised implementation of Employment Policy, the first draft of the guidance tool completed in December 2019 and the methodology will be presented in second half of 2020. After the presentation, the tool will be finalized. At sub-regional level, UNDP and EIF agreed to conceptualize a joint financing instrument for SME development and job creation in the Western Balkans. The Inclusive Growth Facility aims at crowding in private sector financing to generate jobs, expand skills building opportunities and trigger territorial development in the Western Balkans. The instrument envisages an SDG-aligned impact measurement framework which will form a solid basis for monitoring the impact of the inclusive employment actions on the achievement of SDGs at the local level.

3.1. At least 3 countries/territory develop models for effective engagement and contribution of the private sector to inclusive employment actions at local level. 3.2. In 3 countries/territory local stakeholders have access to new and innovative products and mechanisms for financing of employment, business start-ups and social services 3.3. 3 countries/territory have agreed on the local targets, data collection and monitoring of employment and social protection related SDGs

description.narrative: A regional IF is established as a complement to the mutual learning programme to support innovations that address inclusiveness challenges in the implementation of labour market policies.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative:
4.1. # of “inclusiveness-oriented” actions/changes related programmes, services, and service-delivery modalities implemented by the PESs of WB6 and Moldova
4.2. #countries that implement additional actions to improve performance measurement of employment outcomes

comment.narrative: 4.1. 0 – None of the WB6 or Moldova implements inclusiveness oriented actions 4.2. 0

4.1. Albania – comprehensive package on decent work (for NAES staff and clients): Update of the ILO training package on Youth Rights@Work and adaptation of the programme according to the Albanian legislation (finalized) Development of the Manual on Decent Work, leaflets and posters for unemployed job seekers (finalized) Bosnia and Herzegovina Development of Occupational Outlook – online tool for informing decision makers, labour market institutions and PES clients about the labour market trends and basis for establishment of sound career guidance services. Technical guidance in design of the Employment Strategy of Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina) Kosovo* Assessment of impact of COVID19 to Roma, Ashkali and Egyptian (RAE) communities in Kosovo, aimed to inform Government and KEA for creation of effective active labour market programmes targeting these vulnerable communities (December 2020) Support to development of the statistical profiling system - technical advise on improvement of the existing profiling system. Technical report and recommendations provided (September 2019) Feasibility study for introduction of new career guidance services (request under consideration). Montenegro - technical support in improvement of the draft legislation related to the promotion of the employment for persons with disabilities: Technical guidance and advise for improvement of the draft law on the professional rehabilitation and employment of persons with disabilities Guidelines for provision of Work Ability Assessment for EAM North Macedonia - technical assistance to strengthen institutional and operational capacity of ESA to implement the Youth Guarantee (technical report and capacity building workshop) Serbia Training on NEETs characteristics and development of activation strategies. Recommendations integrated in the National Employment Action Plan 2020 (May 2019) 4.2. Due to overload of public employment offices caused by COVID-19 induced disruptions of labour markets implementation of recommendations has been postponed tp 2021

4.1. The Inclusiveness Facility was launched during the Peer-Learning exchange programme in November 2018. Recommendations in the reports from the Participatory Inclusiveness Assessment (phase 1 of the project) and previous peer-learning programmes have been articulated in such a way that representatives of labour market institutions can easily identify the steps required to act upon them. Therefore, stakeholders are able to submit specific requests for TA and policy clinics to the IF.
4.2. Further to the first call, which was opened after the Peer Learning exchange programme ‘Policy instruments to address the challenges of youth not in education, nor employment, or training (NEET) in CEE’, the delegations from Serbia and North Macedonia submitted applications that were in line with the recommendations derived during the peer-learning event. Moldova, a first-time participant in the ‘NEET peer-learning’ has applied to pilot the application of wage-subsides for vulnerable individuals and the new guidelines on workplace accommodation for people with disabilities. Following next round of Peer Learning exchange programme on profiling, Kosovo* submitted first IF request. Montenegrin labour market institutions expressed interest to follow up on recommendations from the phase 1 related to promotion of employment of persons with disabilities. During the phase 1 of the project, all PESs in the Western Balkans conducted a Participatory Inclusiveness Assessment based on the methodology that was developed together with the ILO. All PESs will review existing Action Plans to update and validate proposed measures and actions that are still relevant. Validation and assessment of the Action Plans will be done with the support of the ILO technical team and validated actions will be eligible for IF funding. Details on use of IF (country, applying institution, title of action, purpose, total amount used) Republic of Serbia, Ministry of Labour, Employment, Veteran and Social Affairs; Knowledge development training on NEETs characteristics in Serbia and development of adequate activation strategies; Preparation of a set of training materials for the capacity development on NEETs characteristics, profiling methods, outreach and activation strategies as a precondition for development of evidence based policy instruments and delivery of a 2-day training on NEETs and activation strategies to representatives of the labour market institutions. The advisory report emerging from this activity has fed into the implementation of the National Employment Action Plan 2020 and contextually proposes policy interventions to be subsumed by the National Employment Strategy 2021-2030 when the design process starts (April 2019, 8.500 EUR) Republic of North Macedonia, Ministry of Labour and Social Policy, Technical assistance to review the implementation of the Youth Guarantee, Review of the existing legislation with respect to its compatibility with the Youth Guarantee in EU and facilitation of a stakeholders’ workshop on the YG implementation plan (review of progress and formulation of recommendations for the new YG implementation plan (2020-2022). Based on the new YG implementation plan formulated with the technical guidance of the ILO, the Government of North Macedonia will receive 17 million Euro sectoral budget support for the YG (May 2019, 12.200 EUR) Republic of Moldova, Public Employment Service, Technical Assistance to PES; Development of monitoring and evaluation tools to adjust services and programmes to the specific needs of vulnerable individuals (May 2019, 12.000 EUR) Kosovo*, Employment Agency of Kosovo, Support to development of the statistical profiling system; Request was submitted in June 2019 and assistance has been provided in September and October 2019. During the field visit ILO technical team determined possibilities for improvement of the existing profiling system and provided recommendations for next steps that will be determined in Q1 of 2020 in agreement with Kosovo Employment Agency management. Republic of North Macedonia, Employment Service Agency, Technical assistance to strengthen institutional and operational capacity of ESA to implement the Youth Guarantee throughout the country; Request was submitted in October 2019 and assistance provided in November and December 2019 resulting with preparation of the technical report and capacity building workshop for 30 ESA staff was held in December 2019. Montenegro, Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare initiated request for technical support regarding improvement of the draft legislation related to the promotion of the employment for persons with disabilities. Support will be provided in Q1 2020.
4.1. At least 3 per country 4.2. 3 countries/territory

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative:
Secondment: Please refer to MoA between the Ministry of Environment, the Republic of Korea and UNDP, for support to the Regional Bureau for Asia and the Pacific in Bangkok, Thailand through the assignment of an Environment Advisor
Regional Programme Support: Please refer to Regional Project Document

comment.narrative:
1. Sustainable, scalable solutions tested towards green and blue economy transformation – focusing particularly on circular economy and livelihoods in urban/SIDS context targeting displaced groups.
2. Accelerating environmental and climate action & building climate resilient communities (Climate change; SDG localization; Urbanization; Gender; SDG finance; Innovation; Partnerships).
3. Enhanced RBAP Support on the Climate Promise – Encouraging more countries to commit to higher ambitions or existing countries to do more and better by utilizing the unique opportunities of Climate Promise to elevate peer-to-peer learning and foster collective momentum

1.1 Regional initiative implemented in Maldives and Iran on waste management: Maldives: 1) one circular economy waste management concept has been developed, 2) two institutions have been enabled to carry out exploratory work to scale up green waste management models. Iran: three analytical reports are developed : 1- Baseline and situation analysis on municipal waste management, 2-Systematic assessment of particular waste streams and 3- Gap analysis of digital waste management in Tehran city and recommended solutions. 1.2 contributed to COs requests for support on blue economy strategies development and strategic and practical guidance on various innovative tools and instruments and with a special focus on marine spatial planning 1.3 Supported establishment of ImpactAIM Vietnam (focused on plastic pollution), and planning of impact venture accelerators in India (focused on renewables and women empowerment) that partially were funded through Planet track for related IMM inputs.
2.1 Integrated Urban Resilience initiative: One conceptual framework developed; pilot-testing in Cox’ Bazar (Bangladesh), Waling (Nepal), and Rawalpindi (Pakistan). 2.2 One stock-taking report developed for sharing the relevant examples in/outside UNDP with the COs. 2.3 Two proposals developed for Pakistan CO to support the government of Rawalpindi to establish a data repository, complementing the ongoing urban resilience initiative, and for Malaysia CO to support the development of urban development policy for the Sarawak State Government, highlighting a similar approach to the urban resilience initiative. Both proposals were developed in collaboration with the Singapore Centre. 2.4 One proposal developed for scaling up the ongoing initiative in 10 cities across the region and mobilizing fund together with the Resilience Cities Network (R-Cities). 2.5 One concept note on the upcoming webinars developed, which will be organized in 2021.
3.1 Regional Climate Promise Dialogues/Webinars facilitated to promote cross-boundary collaboration* [3 virtual peer-to-peer dialogues were conducted for the sharing of lesson learned and challenges on youth, gender and climate finance targeting selected CC focal points, SDG and gender focal points of COs].
* Q2-Q4 COVID-19 Pandemic: Switched to online support (seminars, webinars, training, etc.)
3.2 Enhanced support to RBAP COs for CP implementation – Facilitating “peer-to-peer” learning experiences and cross-cutting and cluster support* [On-demand Peer Review/Quality Assurance]
* Q2-Q4 COVID-19 Pandemic: Switched to online support (online on-demand peer review and quality assurance) "3.3 Targeted capacity building for government technical officers* [CLEWS training workshop attended by representatives from 8 countries (in collaboration with AIT, UNDESA, UNESCAP, KTH and Loughborough University)]
* Q2-Q4 COVID-19 Pandemic: Switched to online support
3.4 Supported Country Offices in providing technical assistance, knowledge exchanges and targeted technical capacity building to deliver on Updated/Enhanced NDCs of Bangladesh, Cambodia, Maldives, Mongolia, Nepal, Papua New Guinea, Thailand, Tonga, and Viet Nam were submitted to the UNFCCC.

description.narrative: 1.1 National HTA guidelines 1.2 Expert visits to support SFDA in building capacities 2.1 Quality assurance practice documents 2.2 Report on assessment of health technologies used at healthcare providers in order to ensure their quality and safe use

comment.narrative: Saudi Food and Drug Authority completed the implementation of its First Strategic Plan for 2007-2011 and its Second Strategic Plan for 2012-2016
Develop HTA guidelines for technologies relevant for SFDA, i.e. drug and medical devices

inspection staff were well trained and well informed with respect to the context of the sample collection and that they can provide feedback on any constraints or difficulties they encounter during sample collection. A technical assistance to SFDA was provided in revising the Integrated Annual National Monitoring and Control Plan with the aim of becoming more risk based. Data documenting previous sampling results were collated, cleaned and summarised, to provide an indication of the contamination levels found and thus to inform future sampling efforts. Data sets were based around food-borne hazard categories, including: Microbiology; Pesticides; Veterinary Residues; Contaminants and Quality Tests.
Development of safety and safety assessment of medicines and medical devices

• Update six internal pharmaceutical preparations bulletins regarding drug safety. • Requesting additional information from nine marketed companies regarding drug safety. • Update the list of analyzed pesticides, activate the analysis of tobacco samples, and address some technical problems • A plan has been made to establish a specialized center to supply competency samples, in partnership with colleagues in the Laboratory Development Center • Distributing warning messages to health care providers for one product

Enhancing confidence in the authority's role locally and internationally, to develop food legislation to improve the nutritional pattern, to increase community awareness of products subject to the authority’s control and enhancing international cooperation and participation

description.narrative:
1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses.
2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Network have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

comment.narrative:
1.1) 5 new data sources per lab 1.2) 6 different data sources per lab. 1.3) 35 new potential solutions per lab 1.4) 5 per Action Plan
2.1) At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2) At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3) At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4) At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
3.1) Each lab should interact at least once a week with another lab, a partner, and the global team. 3.2) 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related 3.3) The Accelerator Lab Networks' work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4) Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media.Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries. 1.1 & 1.2.) 5 new data sources per lab 6 different data sources per lab. The AccLab introduced various data sources including primary data collection. The findings and insights were reflected in the following reports “Human-Centred smart Cities: Inclusion”, “Rapid Impact Assessment of COVID-19 on Beneficiaries”, “Rapid Assessment of Digital Economy”, “The Future of Work: Risks and Opportunities Through Eyes of RBEC Accelerator Lab”, “Plastic Pollution in Sumqayit” and “The Impact of COVID-19 on the Private Sector” together with the CO. 1.3) 53 solutions have been collected on the topics such as COVID-19 and water-related challenges. Moreover, 200 recycling solutions have been submitted through the OzunYarat platform, which has been set to promote upcycling in the country. 1.4) To achieve the results, the Accelerator Lab introduced several tools such as a crowdsourcing platform, co-designing, hackathon, collective intelligence, and prototyping.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1) 10 blogs and 13 press releases 2.2) 53 solutions have been presented to the government. 2.3) The uptake of the designed solutions by the government was high. 8 out of 8 healthcare-related prototypes were further managed by the Ministry of Health. Moreover, the Ministry of Transport, Communications, and High Technologies have co-designed and scaled up the one-stop digital platform with all e-services available in Azerbaijan during COVID-19. 2.4) Almost all new projects designed by the CO were prepared together with the AccLab, which exceeds the target of 15% CO programming influenced by the AccLab Network. The team has been working closely with the UNDP programme advisors in designing and implementing projects by mainstreaming digital transformation. Those are "Vocational Education Programme", "COVID-19 Rapid Response Facility", "SDG Joint Programme", "EU Capacity Building of CSOs and Promoting of the Social Entrepreneurship", "Addressing GBV through comprehensive and coordinated community effort", "EU4Lankaran", and “Enabling A Disability-Centered Approach To Covid-19 Recovery In Azerbaijan”.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1) The lab interacts with other labs through formal and informal channels. On top of that, the Head of Exploration organized and run the AccLab Explorer call and Steering Committee of the Explorer Global Summit. 3.2) The lab has exceeded the expectation of sharing 5% of the methodologies and other opportunities across the network. The Head of Experimentation together with the other colleagues across the region was a part of the organizing team of the Istanbul Innovation Days. Moreover, one of the solutions designed by the AccLab team has been replicated by the UNDP CO in the Maldives. 3.3) Total reach on social media 402570; reach of Ozun Yarat platform 170,000 visitors 3.4) The AccLab members have been actively driving the conversation in the innovation ecosystem by participating in over 10 innovation-themed events including iclimathon in Pakistan. The AccLab has been leading the preparation and implementation of the Innoweek, which aims to spread innovative ideas in our country, expand the startup movement, develop innovative thinking among young people. Furthermore, to connect ecosystem players and facilitate joint efforts and innovative solutions to tackle the challenge, #STEMhamiuchundur (#STEMisforeveryone) has started to encourage more young women and girls to advance in STEM fields.
NOTE: The AccLab team has been implementing or completed 14 initiatives on employment, social services, e-healthcare, green solutions, and gender equality. Although AccLab has been heavily focused on the pandemic response, 21% of the initiatives were exploring areas outside the ongoing COVID-19 response. The team has contributed towards seven SDGs such as SDG 3 on good health, SDG 5 on gender equality, SDG 6 on clean water, SDG 8 on economic growth, SDG 9 on innovation, SDG 12 on responsible consumption, and SDG 13 on climate action.

1.1) 2 new sources of data per lab 1.2) 3 different data sources per Lab. 1.3) 20 new potential solutions per lab 1.4) 2 per Action Plan
2.1) 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2) At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3) At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4) At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
3.1) Each lab should interact at least once a week with another lab, a partner, and the global team. 3.2) 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3) The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4) Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries. 1.1 & 1.2.) The Acclab team has been on board since September 2019. The lab introduced new data sources in exploring people with disabilities frontier challenge. The sources are data from the State Statistical Committee, data from Civil Society Organizations, data from reports of the partnering agencies. 1.3) The lab identified 16 solutions for people with disabilities. 1.4) The team has introduced two innovative methods: hackathon and sensemaking.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1) 1 blog post, 3 press realeses 2.2) 16 solutions were presented to the government counterparts for further consideration. 2.3) The team has reached a 5% proportion that increases the uptake of the innovation methods included in the AccLab Network suite. 2.4) The AccLab started working together with four programme advisors to incorporates its methodologies through ongoing projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1) The lab interacts with other labs through formal and informal channels. 3.2) The lab has exceeded the expectation of sharing 5% of the methodologies and other opportunities across the network. 3.3) Total reach in social media 132800 3.4) The AccLab members have been actively driving the conversation in the innovation ecosystem. As evidenced by the participation in women in STEM events in Poland, the interviews in the largest learning network Ekinchi.
NOTE: The additional following results has been achieved in 2019: (1) The representatives from 83 institutions, which include embassies, international organizations, chambers of commerce, and goverment agencies, participated at the launch. (2) The team has organized all Staff Retreat with the focus on innovation methodologies. (3) The team has designed a joint proposal with the UNICEF country team following the call of the Administrator.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 5 new sources of data per year 1.2 6 different type of data sources per year 1.3 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 5 innovation methods per Action Plan.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart 2.3 At least one government entity has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network (48 interaction per year)
3.2 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related.
3.3 The Accelerator Lab Networks' work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account.
3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1.1) 5 new data sources per year: the lab provided 7 new data sources; 1) The AccLab in Iraq reached 710 youth from across the country, divided into students, unemployed and employed graduates, and youth who participated in the experimented local solutions mapped by the AccLab to simulate their brains using the Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) based on real data collected through a survey. 2) The AccLab used the Words and Hashtags on social media as a source of data. The algorithms of social media platforms are designed to assist users in finding information. The AccLab observed the trending words (hashtags) and connected the dots to build understanding of what is going on in the community and find local solutions. 3) The AccLab reached the community through an online survey to investigate people's interest and willingness to participate in climate change initiatives. The aim is to gauge people’s interest and 4) The AccLab in Iraq used Social Media questions feature to test local community knowledge about climate change challenges and the current climate actions to tackle the challenge. This provided the AccLab with an informal but desirable way to find information about the local community, as well as use it as a way to promote climate action. 5) The UNDP AccLab in Iraq initiated Mapping Signals of change Activity to gather signals and new trends caused by the pandemic, and established a sensor network to support the work of the AccLab. The UNDP-AccLab started mapping signals of change in April amid the spread of COVID-19 and it is an on-going process that is continuing till now. 6) Gathering information about the geographical spread of COVID-19 in Iraq through the symptoms-tracker feature through Corona in Iraq Platform; it is a digital platform which was launched in April 2020, continues to Raising awareness on the symptoms and risks of, as well as combat misinformation about, the COVID-19 virus. This platform showed the government, the potential OVID-19 cases and provide a geographical overview of emerging COVID-19 hotspots. 7) UNDP AccLab in Iraq supported the establishment of The Karbala ‘Spatial Data Infrastructure’ (SDI) to track and trace COVID-19 using modern geographic information system (GIS) technologies. This platform was one the sources of information to Karbala Governorate in Iraq.
1.2) 6 different type of data sources per year: the lab have 8 different type of sources; 1) Machine Data (Artificial Intelligence) 2) Citizen Generated Data 3) Social Network Data 4) Perception Surveys 5) Social Media Data 6) Sensor and Sensor Network Data 7) Google Analytics 8) GIS Data.
1.3) 35 new potential solutions per lab per year: 100 local solutions mapped for Youth and Unemployment, Climate Change and COVID-19 challenges. Two of the mapped solutions received the Honey Bee’s Network HBNCRIIA 2020 Award. Also, 6 of the solutions are funded from the Rapid Financing Facility V02 with amount equal to $135 k. One Local solutions has handed over to a government institution.
1.4) 5 innovation methods used: The Lab used 8 different methods; 1) Human Centered Design - experimentation of three local solutions out of 100 mapped local solutions; Design Thinking Training Manual, INpoint platform, and Corona in Iraq Platform. 2)Future Thinking - The First Future of Climate Exhibition in Iraq. 3) Foresight – Mapping Signals of Change, Blended Learning Initiative with Education Sector. 4) System Thinking – to better formulate the graduation projects with market need. 5) Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning - Simulate 710 youth brains using the Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs). 6)Design Thinking 7) Social Media Analysis 8) Ethnography.
2.1) At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year: The Accelerator Lab wrote 10 Blogs and 1 story: 1) Discovering Beyond the Known During 2020: Innovative Approaches from UNDP Accelerator Lab in Iraq. 2) Stories from the future of climate in Iraq- A future perspective to sense and explore climate change challenge in Iraq. 3) Artificial Neural Networks Simulation in Identifying Local Solutions in Iraq-Artificial Intelligence to sense and explore youth unemployment challenge in Iraq. 4) Design Thinking Methodology: Experimenting Local Solutions in Iraq-Experimentation of innovative methodologies to tackle COVID-19, Climate change and youth unemployment challenges in Iraq. 5) Signals spark strategic direction: COVID-19 Pandemic uncovers new opportunities for education in Iraq- A future perspective to tackle youth unemployment challenge in Iraq. 6) The Learning Waves of Climate Change Status-Quo in Iraq-Sensing, and exploring climate change challenge in Iraq. 7) Finding local solutions through the power of words and communication patterns-Local Solutions Strategy in Iraq. 8) Empowering women in business during unstable times- Tackling youth unemployment challenge within women in Iraq. 9) From symptoms to solutions – new local innovation helps Iraqi communities manage Coronavirus concerns. 10) Exploring Innovation in Iraq- Exploration of youth unemployment challenge in Iraq. 11) Story: Iraqis sharing their vision for the future of climate in Iraq.
2.2) At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart: 1) Ministry of Youth and Sport (MoYS) - The UNDP AccLab in cooperation with GIZ and MoYS and other international and local actors in Iraq are working towards laying the ground for formalizing startups in Iraq. 2) Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research MoHESR – Sensing and Exploring the Teaching Methods inside the Iraqi Universities and how this affecting the employability in Iraq. 3) Ministry of Health and Environment (MoHE)- Together to understand the priorities of the locals in regard to climate change challenges through using a gamified method to sense and explore the prioritized challenges; Mission 1.5 and local solutions. 4) The Station Foundation for Entrepreneurship (NGO) - scan, sense, explore and forecast the future of climate through “The Future of Climate in Iraq Exhibition” 5) University of Basrah - College of Agriculture - investigate sustainable agriculture and its role in economic and human development. 6) CS50x Iraq (Private Sector) experimenting the effectiveness of the programming companies on the youth and unemployment challenge.
2.3) At least one government entity has learned about Accelerator lab methods: 1) Design Thinking Methodology used by University of Basrah – College of Agriculture to formulate graduation projects for the students to match the market need. 2) Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research MoHESR adopted the Mapping Signals of Change approach and came up with the Blended Learning Initiative, one of the biggest initiatives of the lab in 2020. 4) Ministry of Communication - Iraqi Communications and Media Commission – adopted one of the AccLab local solutions, Corona in Iraq Platform.
2.4) At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects: 1) UNDP -Environment Energy and Climate Change pillar (EECC) team - the results of the “The Future of Climate in Iraq Exhibition” is recognized by the EECC team and build on the results a 1-year activity to engage the locals in supporting the climate in Iraq. Also, The Acc Lab and EECC performed Systems-Mapping for Climate Change in Iraq that resulted in conducting a baseline study to determine the status-quo. 2) UNDP-Youth Leadership Programme – the way of work of the lab was adopted by YLP team to launch a Call for Innovations: Ideation Challenge on Climate Change. This call for innovation aimed to analyze the climate change challenges and the ideation of potential solutions using the Design Thinking methodology based on the lab’s identified challenges with a target audience of the active Youth Service Organizations (YSOs) in Iraq. 3) UNDP- Iraq Crisis Response and Resilience Program (ICRRP) – funded 2 local solutions from the lab based on the challenges that tackle; COVID-Venture and Eco-Bags local solutions. Also, the ICRRP will conduct a Call for Innovation for the identified lab’s challenges, they also funded this activity. 4) UNDP Gender team - The UNDP AccLab supported the UNDP Gender Division team through sharing the knowledge extracted from the community with the new members of the first Gender Responsive Crisis Chamber in Iraq (GRCC). The UNDP- AccLab structured a Call for Innovations with 13 women leaders from local organizations and government representatives for three weeks which was concluded with an Innovation Day to showcase results.
3.1) The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network (48 interaction per year): 1) Holding active discussion by WhatsApp and Microsoft Teams at the global, regional and network level (Experimenters, Solutions Mappers and Explorers), 2) Generating reflections and discussion in the frame of the Solutions Mapping Course, 3) Co-organizing and facilitating the Explorers´ Summit, 4) Participating to support the establishment of 2nd cohort labs in the region. 5) sharing the 100 local solutions on the global platform of the local solutions.
3.2) 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related: 1) Sharing the Solutions Mapping strategy amid COVID-19 to the solutions mappers during the Solutions Mapping Course by HBN. 2) Sharing the Solutions Safari platform as a prototype for engaging the community with the local solutions 3) Sharing the Iraq’s combination of using the Future Thinking with arts in order for the communities to represent their thoughts of the future of climate. 4) Sharing the approach of Simulating the reality of youth and unemployment in Iraq through using the Artificial Intelligence. 5) The lab shared its approach on utilizing the power of words and communication patterns, to build a strategy for tapping into insight and mapping local innovations. 6) sharing the massive work of the Mapping Signals of Change and imaging the future.
3.3) The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account: The lab’s work was regularly mentioned through the official channels of UN in addition Mr. Achim Steiner wrote two original tweets about the work of the Accelerator Lab in Iraq. We can highlight the below posts; UNAMI announcing UNDP-Acc Lab in Iraq Future of Climate in Iraq Exhibition, UNDP Arab States publishing about UNDP-Acc Lab in Iraq blog, UNDP Arab States publishing about Acc Lab in Iraq work on signals of Change, Achim Steiner publishing about UNDP acc Lab in Iraq work on Climate change, UNDP Accelerator Labs publishing about Acc lab Iraq work on youth and unemployment, UNDP Accelerator Labs publish about Iraq Acc Lab work on climate change, UNDP Accelerator Lab publishing about UNDP-Acc Lab in Iraq work on local solutions, UNFPA publish about UNDP Acc Lab in Iraq work on youth empowerment in Iraq, UNDP SDG Integration Climate Change, UNDP Iraq publish about the Exploration summit, Accelerator Lab publish about the explorers Summit, UNDP-Iraq publish about blended-learning.
3.4) Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem: The lab was actively participated in the local events, hackathons and discussions and build a good relationship with the local partners. We can mention the following visibility of the lab with non-UN partners 1) UTV channel featuring Iraq’s movement to promote for tackling climate change 2) Iraq Radio Al-Salam announcing about UNDP Acc Lab The future of Climate in Iraq Exhibition 3) The Station for Entrepreneurship Foundation announcing about UNDP Acc Lab support Raa’dait Project. 4) The Station for Entrepreneurship Foundation about UNDP Acc Lab The future of Climate in Iraq Exhibition. 5) Financial Budgeting Lectures - Raa’idat - The Station. 6) Co-organization in 2 hackathons.
*The UNDP AccLab has experimented 5 hypotheses; (1- if we build a volunteer community service team from the different geographical areas and sectors of Iraq then we will be able to identify priority challenges, effectively explore innovative solutions, disperse the new way of thinking about development, build local partnerships to pursue local agendas, and scale-up innovative solutions, 2- If we followed the flowing words of the virtual community around the Accelerator Lab, then these words could be employed as our key to find and scale up the local solutions, thus the signal of change would be the innovators paying more attention to their words on the virtual world., 3- If the Design Thinking methodology is used with the community, then more people will be interested in focusing on climate change and increase their sense of responsibility towards the environment., 4- “If the Design Thinking Training Manual is used as an educational tool in designing local innovations then the designers will be better at identifying the roots of complex problems thus they will be able to ideate for more practical innovations”, 5- If Design Thinking Methodology is used to design the experimentation processes of INpoint platform, then behaviors and insights of target people will be extracted, thus developing the platform’s users experience.).

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.

The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account.
3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

PS: The Lab started in September 2019 and the main challenge was the uncompleted Accelerator Lab Iraq Team, since the 100 days Plan was solo drafted by the Head of Solutions Mapping and the Accelerator Lab Focal Point, while missing the input and cooperation of the Head of the Exploration and Head of Experimentation members and the Head of Solution’s Mapping had to perform all the tasks of Experimentation and Exploration with the guidance of the focal point. the team was completed in February, 2020.
Executive Summary of the Results: 100 Days Plan for the UNDP Accelerator Lab in Iraq aimed at sense-making, exploring, and testing with the local community in Iraq, while actively building partnerships with decision-makers to highlight the main issues within youth and unemployment and to pave the way towards identifying local Iraqi solutions. The UNDP Accelerator Lab - Iraq identified the following priorities: develop and localize innovative global methodologies to fit the Accelerator Lab work in Iraq, and find and experiment one local solution related to youth and unemployment; while focusing on building a collaborative voluntary team “Accelerator Lab Community Service Team”. To achieve the proposed objectives, the Accelerator Lab performed (5) workshops, (2) events to perform sense-making activities, and (6) meetings. The meetings, workshops and events were held with government officials, private sector representatives and NGOs in Erbil and Baghdad to build partnerships and establish the foundation for a supportive ecosystem. The audience of the activities included representatives of government institutions, university teachers, private sector, local and international NGOs, youth initiatives, co-working spaces, entrepreneurs, and UN agencies. The Accelerator Lab methodologies while directing the discussions and analysis of the current structural problems in youth and unemployment in Iraqi’s ecosystem were Systemic Thinking, Design Thinking, Systemic-Design Thinking and Collective Intelligence methodologies. The Lab conducted one successful experiment in 2019 to test one of the main local solutions found by the Accelerator Lab (The localized Design Thinking Training Manual) and to validate its hypothesis of the 100 days action plan. The results of the tested methodologies within the audience resulted in rich analysis regarding youth and unemployment and led the Accelerator Lab to identify the main issue within youth and unemployment in Iraq which is “Tunnel-Vision of Employment”. The Accelerator Lab conducted a workshop in Erbil with 35 activists from all over Iraq to collect intelligence and use it to identify the main obstacles within youth and unemployment in Iraq, and after three days of analysis, using the adopted methodologies, the audience prioritized the issue of “Tunnel-Vision of Employment. The Accelerator Lab took this issue further and aimed at understanding all its angles through holding a workshop with government officials to discuss and analyze the issue of “Tunnel-Vision of Employment” amongst youth. The discussion and analysis resulted in building on two opportunities one with the Department of Human Development at the Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research and the General Directorate for Industrial Development at the Ministry of Industry and Minerals.

description.narrative: 1. Enhanced capacity on climate change adaptation and disaster risk management; a model for Resilient Community/City is developed in Zhouqu and can be shared with the world. 2. Developed community-based smart resilience solutions that is institutionalizable for county-level emergency response management; systematically enhanced capacity for comprehensive disaster prevention and response; 3. Capacity developed for gender-responsive disaster prevention and mitigation as well as climate change adaptation. 4. Compiliation of the “Green Book of Resilience Building and Sustainable Development of Zhouqu County”; 5. Establishment of a county-level coordination network for building resilient cities and a platform for international knowledge sharing and exchange. 6. Improved capacity on entrepreneurship and poverty alleviation for left-behind groups in order to provide new kinetic energy for poverty reduction in Zhouqu County through increasing the yield of high-quality agricultural products and unit landuse efficiency, as well as feasibility studies and demonstration of vertical farming and livestock farming. 7. A cold chain logistics system constructed and linked with the “E-commerce Demonstration County Project”; introduction of leading e-commerce enterprises to support left-behind groups to engage in e-commerce entrepreneurship, enhanced competitiveness of local quality products that accelerates of poverty reduction in Zhouqu County. 8. Feasibility study and pilots carried out to upgrade and rennovate existing waste treatment facilities in the local area, adhering to the requirements of local policies and regulations. 9. Appropriate sewage treatment technology identified and piloted. 10. Ensured drinking water safety for communities and students. 11. Feasibility studies and pilots conducted on the utilization of renewable energy such as micro-hydropower, biogas and micro-wind turbines in cold chain logistics system. 12. Compilation of the Featured Tourism Development Pla

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: N/A

comment.narrative: N/A
Component 2: Preparation of NC4 and BUR 1 Turkmenistan under the UNFCCC. Duration – 36 months.

1. NC4 and BUR1 Project Implementation Plan (PIP) prepared - Achieved 2. NC4 and BUR1 reports prepared and submitted to the UNFCCC.- Partially achieved (on-going)
(This result has been achieved through preparation of the detailed PIP in April-June 2020. PIP provides a clear description of project environment for undertaking an assignment; the expected methodology and workplan, including timing and duration; costs for proposed activities and terms of references for the project personnel. The process of PIP preparation included using participatory working techniques and respect local knowledge and skills. Local experts took a lead role in the identification and formulation of the project design. Project costs are presented using GEF Trust Fund’s budget and Government co-financing. Project design document is presented clearly/concisely and in an appropriate language. This document will be used throughout the project cycle to guide the planned scope of work.) (The project is in the initial stage at the moment and it is progressing according to the work plan. The adaptation group carried out a preliminary analysis of climate risks in Turkmenistan. A template “List of adaptation measures aimed at reducing risks in the context of climate change” has been prepared. The template will be submitted to all interested ministries and agencies. Appropriate methodologies were selected for assessing vulnerability and adaptation. The analysis of results of various national and regional projects related to adaptation in the context of climate change was carried out with purpose to update technical assessments according to current conditions for further work on NC4/BUR1. A template has been prepared on mitigation component for collecting and processing data on GHG emissions. Consultations were held with the team and Technical Advisor of the UNDP project on energy efficiency in water management. Analysis of results and technical assessments of pilot projects were carried out for effective use within the framework of NC4/BUR1 project. Analysis of results of the UNDP project on energy efficiency in residential sector was carried out with purpose to update technical assessments according to current conditions for further discussion in NC4/BUR1 project.)

Goals:
Component 1: Preparation of Project Implementation Plans (PIPs) for NCs and BURs: The PIP will outline proposed project activities; activity costs/component and workplan; roles, responsibilities and draft Terms of References (ToRs) of institutions/representatives; and will act as a tool for monitoring the performance of the projects in terms of its scope, budget and schedule.
Component 2: Preparation of NCs and BURs. This phase of the project will be initiated once the PIPs prepared under component I have been approved and signed by the Executing Agency (EA) and the UN Environment. Duration 36 months.
Component 3: National stakeholders’ involvement and institutional arrangements for subsequent NC and BUR. Duration: This component will provide an opportunity for the Recipient and Cooperating Agencies to undertake national stocking exercise for subsequent NCs and BURs after completion of their NCs and BURs under Component II.

Expected outcome:
Component 1: NC4 and BUR1 Project Implementation Plan (PIP) prepared
Component 2: NC4 and BUR1 reports for Turkmenistan prepared and submitted to the UNFCCC.
Component 3: National stakeholder’s engagement and institutional arrangement for preparation of subsequent NC & BUR undertaken
Component 2: Preparation of NC4 and BUR 1 Turkmenistan under the UNFCCC. Duration – 36 months.

description.narrative: Indicator 1.1: # of dedicated officers in MWCSD to monitor effectiveness of communications campaign Indicator 2.1: Number of households in Samoa reached by mobile blasts and radio spots.

comment.narrative: Baseline 1.1: One dedicated officer in MWCSD Baseline 2.1: 0 households reached by mobile blasts and dedicated radio spots

Target 1.1. Statistician hired and seconded to the Policy and Research Division of the MWCSD for data and information gathering during and after the campaign. Target 2.1. Mobile text blasts sent out to all DIGICEL and BLUESKY customers, which is about 90% of the population (195,843, 2017 Population Census), reaching even the most isolated families. Target 2.2. Airing of messaging on radio networks. Target 2.3. Transportation and access to isolated families provided. Target 3.1. Hiring of short-term local surge capacity (21 working days).

Output 1. Augmentation of coordination efforts by the MWCSD through embedding of technical capacity in the Ministry focusing on Monitoring and Evaluation of the community awareness raising campaign, through the conduct of an impact study Output 2. Rapidity of anti-measles messaging reaching the general public enhanced through effective use of digital means to prevent the spread of the measles disease Output 3. UNDP Samoa’s capacity for coordination and liaison as well as reporting on UNDP’s contribution to the One UN measles response strengthened.

OUTPUT 1 1.1 Two Dedicated Officers in MWCSD for 20 Days
OUTPUT 2 2.1 100% of Households in Samoa reached through Rapidity Anti-Measles Messaging

UNDP supported the Ministry of Women, Community and Social Development to conduct an impact assessment of the Community Development Sector Response Awareness Campaign conducted during the recent measles epidemic in Q4. The impact assessment shows that there has been an increase in the public’s level of awareness and understanding on measles. Moreover, evidence highlights that delivering awareness campaigns through the use of a combination of means of communication is more effective than distributing printed materials. Furthermore, the assessment found that the messages received by the informants were helpful in understanding facts about measles and the importance of vaccination. The lessons from the impact assessment were absorbed by the Ministry to inform the COVID community outreach and awareness campaign.

1.1 Preliminary on research in drug pricing analysis including international price information for ATM drugs; other drugs and vaccines. 1.2 Draft of multisector collaboration framework to improve access to affordable medicines for vulnerable people, key affected population, women and children 1.3. Gap analysis on ATM drug stock out in last 10 years in Indonesia; Study on procurement and supply chain management for planning, procurement to distribution goods in an emergency as a recommendation to accelerate the process on disaster recovery responses. 1.4 Provide technical assistance to improve national program of AIDS, TB, and Malaria implementation performance benefitting both women and men

UNDP with the Ministry of Health were nducted the virtual workshop series on the medicines price regulation for Indonesia and disseminated the comparison study analysis in relevant to the issue mentioned. This has proceeded the progress on advocacy made for the affordable medicine to all people. In 2020, the advocacy on ARV Fix Dose Combination (FDC) price reduction was successfully achieved with about 50% reduction price which is registered on the national e-catalogue. in addition, UNDP has supported the CCM Secretariat and technical assistance for The Global Fund proposal 2021-2023. The supports to MoH on financial and human resources management, has resulted the support of planning renovation for MDR TB services in 41 hospitals.

description.narrative: Immediate Crisis Support to Government of China in Fight Against COVID-19, mainly focus on social and economic assessment
second-order administrative division

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: At least 4-6 counties social and economic assessment done

comment.narrative: N/A
At least 4-6 counties social and economic assessment done

First, the CO supported China's emergency response and recovery by focusing on vulnerable populations. This included saving lives of COVID-19 patients who were critically ill and front-line responders, through the provision of medical equipment (584,374 USD of clinical electrocardiogram monitors, infusion pumps, 10,000 sets of protective clothing). Second, the CO provided technical leadership on the UN socio-economic impact assessment, which provides insights on effective policy prescriptions, particularly that with a focus on the pandemic's impact on the most vulnerable. Drawing from the assessment findings sampling 5044 individuals in 1,183 households, UNDP utilized the TRAC resources in 5 counties across 5 provinces in China for recovery support. Third, the CO implemented activities to help the most vulnerable population to build back better. Urgent livelihood needs of 400 vulnerable households (1,600 villagers) in Zhangwan (Hubei) were addressed due to UNDP's support on live streaming for e-commerce. Local farmers attracted 2.1 million customers through the livestreaming and increased their sales. Challenges in managing information and finance for local businesses were addressed as UNDP set up an information management platform, currently used by 8 businesses. Fourth, the CO enhanced local public health and other basic social services, including education, in Neixiang (Henan), Zhouqu (Gansu) and Yilong (Sichuan), during the COVID and to prepare for future pandemics. 85000 students in Neixiang gained access to psychological support and received better education, as UNDP trained 960 teachers across the county on psychological support and communications. 680 patients (392 are female) in 19 villages directly benefited from the medical equipment donated by UNDP in Zhouqu; 40 doctors and nurses were fully trained to use the donated respiratory machine; 10 clinical electrocardiogram monitors and 50 first-aid kits. In Yilong, 10 villages received PPE and doctors and nurses in 5 hospitals were trained on epidemiology investigation and monitoring. Also, UNDP helped Yilong establish a long-term collaborative network with West China Hospital of Sichuan University to receive continuous technical support and guidance for pandemic control. Additionally, education recovery plans were developed in communities in Chengbu (Hunan) focusing on LNOB. 1,920 teachers have enhanced capacity on online education as UNDP mapped out the local education improvement needs and provided 8 training courses. The 2020 TRAC (175,000 USD) managed to leverage and mobilize another 1,005,046.50 USD to directly benefit 4 additional counties in 4 other provinces, in addition the Zhangwan District of Shiyan City in Hubei, the epicenter of the COVID-19 in 2020, as proposed in the application document.

description.narrative: 1. Extent to which authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina manage to respond to the emergency needs related to COVID-19 disease outbreak in a timely and coordinated manner.

comment.narrative: 1. Target: Highly effective.

The project established partnerships with and provided support to 96 institutional beneficiaries throughout the country, including clinics, hospitals, health care centers, public health institutes, etc. The project has procured and delivered 9,131,137 pieces of various medical goods, health protection and medical waste management supplies ( 33,241 units of clinical management assets and facilities, including more than 2,300 medical devices and equipment; 8,418,865 pieces of personal protective equipment and disinfectants; 455,736 testing material9 and 100 items of laboratory equipment; 132,385 items medicines; 90,760 items for COVID-related medical waste management; and 49 other medical supplies). These interventions significantly increased capacities of local health actors to effectively deal with Covid-19 pandemic even in the cases of extremely high incidence.
1. Target: Highly effective.
